DataElement.preferredName: Congenital Abnormalities of Erythrocyte Differentiation or Function Classification Anemia Hemoglobinopathy Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of inherited abnormalities of erythrocyte differentiation or function classification.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Congenital Abnormalities of Erythrocyte Differentiation or Function Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Inherited disorders involving abnormalities of red blood cell function, structure, or production.  Some diseases in this group may be associated with bone marrow failure, neutropenia, and/or thrombocytopenia._A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Congenital Abnormalities of Erythrocyte Differentiation or Function
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Inherited disorders involving abnormalities of red blood cell function, structure, or production.  Some diseases in this group may be associated with bone marrow failure, neutropenia, and/or thrombocytopenia.

Concepts.longName: Congenital Abnormalities of Erythrocyte Differentiation or Function
Concepts.definition: Inherited disorders involving abnormalities of red blood cell function, structure, or production. Some diseases in this group may be associated with bone marrow failure, neutropenia, and/or thrombocytopenia.

Property.preferredDefinition: Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A reduction in the number of red blood cells per cu mm, the amount of hemoglobin in 100 ml of blood, and the volume of packed red blood cells per 100 ml of blood. Clinically, anemia represents a reduction in the oxygen-transporting capacity of a designated volume of blood, resulting from an imbalance between blood loss (through hemorrhage or hemolysis) and blood production. Signs and symptoms of anemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability._A group of inherited disorders characterized by structural alterations within the hemoglobin molecule._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not characterized in any other way.: A group of hereditary hemolytic anemias in which there is decreased synthesis of one or more hemoglobin polypeptide chains. There are several genetic types with clinical pictures ranging from barely detectable hematologic abnormality to severe and fatal anemia.

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.
An inherited blood disorder characterized by a decreased synthesis of one of the polypeptide chains that form hemoglobin. Anemia results from this abnormal hemoglobin formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare and often fatal inherited disease in which the bone marrow fails to produce red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, or a combination of these cells. The disease may transform into myelodysplastic syndrome or leukemia.

Concepts.definition: An autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by bone marrow failure, skeletal abnormalities, and an increased incidence of the development of neoplasias.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Diamond-Blackfan Anemia PT: Congenital Pure Red Cell Aplasia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Diamond-Blackfan Anemia PT: Congenital Pure Red Cell Aplasia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An inherited condition characterized by aplasia of the erythroid series only. The white cells and platelets are not affected. Patients develop anemia usually in infancy.

Concepts.definition: An inherited condition characterized by aplasia of the erythroid series only. The white cells and platelets are not affected. Patients develop anemia usually in infancy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by exocrine pancreas insufficiency, skeletal abnormalities, bone marrow dysfunction, and an increased incidence of leukemia.

Concepts.definition: A rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by exocrine pancreas insufficiency, skeletal abnormalities, bone marrow dysfunction, and an increased incidence of leukemia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: An inherited disorder characterized by structural alterations of a globin chain within the hemoglobin molecule.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An inherited disorder characterized by structural alterations of a globin chain within the hemoglobin molecule.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells; inherited.: A reduction in the number of red blood cells per cu mm, the amount of hemoglobin in 100 ml of blood, and the volume of packed red blood cells per 100 ml of blood. Clinically, anemia represents a reduction in the oxygen-transporting capacity of a designated volume of blood, resulting from an imbalance between blood loss (through hemorrhage or hemolysis) and blood production. Signs and symptoms of anemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability. --2004

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells.

A reduction in the number of red blood cells, the amount of hemoglobin, and/or the volume of packed red blood cells. Clinically, anemia represents a reduction in the oxygen-transporting capacity of a designated volume of blood, resulting from an imbalance between blood loss (through hemorrhage or hemolysis) and blood production. Signs and symptoms of anemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease characterized by chronic hemolytic anemia, episodic painful crises, and pathologic involvement of many organs. It is the clinical expression of homozygosity for hemoglobin S.

Concepts.definition: A blood disorder characterized by the appearance of sickle-shaped red blood cells and anemia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Hemolytic anemia, in which patients are heterozygous for both the sickle cell gene and a thalassemia gene.

Concepts.definition: Hemolytic anemia, in which patients are heterozygous for both the sickle cell gene and a thalassemia gene.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Severe Aplastic Anemia Not Otherwise Specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Severe Aplastic Anemia Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Life-threatening anemia associated with a high risk of infection or bleeding._Not characterized in any other way.

Concepts.definition: Life-threatening anemia associated with a high risk of infection or bleeding.
Not characterized in any other way.

PermissibleValues.value: Acquired SAA, secondary to toxin / other drug

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A state of bone marrow suppression and failure that is caused by a cytotoxic or adverse immunologic response to a drug treatment, leading to a failure of production of red blood cells, white cells and platelets.

Concepts.definition: A state of bone marrow suppression and failure that is caused by a cytotoxic or adverse immunologic response to a drug treatment, leading to a failure of production of red blood cells, white cells and platelets.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Bone marrow failure defined as pancytopenia, secondary to hepatitis.

Concepts.definition: Bone marrow failure defined as pancytopenia, secondary to hepatitis.

PermissibleValues.value: Acquired Pure Red Cell Aplasia (PRCA) (not congenital)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease characterized by normocytic, normochromic anemia, low hematocrit, reticulocytopenia and selective erythroid hypoplasia. It can occur as a chronic or acute form; the former is predominantly seen in adults and the latter in children. Pathogenesis involves immune dysfunction with antibodies directed against erythroid precursor cells or erythropoietin, or due to T-cell mediated suppression of erythropoiesis.

Concepts.definition: A disease characterized by normocytic, normochromic anemia, low hematocrit, reticulocytopenia and selective erythroid hypoplasia. It can occur as a chronic or acute form; the former is predominantly seen in adults and the latter in children. Pathogenesis involves immune dysfunction with antibodies directed against erythroid precursor cells or erythropoietin, or due to T-cell mediated suppression of erythropoiesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction._Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells._A non-neoplastic, congenital or non-congenital disorder charcaterized by marked reduction or absence of megakaryocytes and thrombocytopenia.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells.
A non-neoplastic, congenital or non-congenital disorder charcaterized by marked reduction or absence of megakaryocytes and thrombocytopenia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells; inherited.: A reduction in the number of blood cells.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Having to do with information that is passed from parents to offspring through genes in sperm and egg cells.
A laboratory test result indicating an abnormally low quantity of circulating blood cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An autosomal recessive disorder that affects the production of beta polypeptide chains which are necessary for the hemoglobin synthesis. Anemia and failure to thrive are characteristic features.

Concepts.definition: An autosomal recessive disorder that affects the production of beta polypeptide chains which are necessary for the hemoglobin synthesis. Anemia and failure to thrive are characteristic features.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare acquired hematologic disorder characterized by hemolytic anemia, dark-colored urine due to the release of hemoglobin in the blood, and thrombosis. The episodes of hemolysis tend to occur at night. It is caused by a somatic mutation in the glycosylphosphatidylinositol biosynthesis gene.

Concepts.definition: A rare acquired hematologic disorder characterized by hemolytic anemia, dark-colored urine due to the release of hemoglobin in the blood, and thrombosis. The episodes of hemolysis tend to occur at night. It is caused by a somatic mutation in the glycosylphosphatidylinositol biosynthesis gene.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A reduction in the number of red blood cells per cu mm, the amount of hemoglobin in 100 ml of blood, and the volume of packed red blood cells per 100 ml of blood. Clinically, anemia represents a reduction in the oxygen-transporting capacity of a designated volume of blood, resulting from an imbalance between blood loss (through hemorrhage or hemolysis) and blood production. Signs and symptoms of anemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability. --2004:A group of inherited disorders characterized by structural alterations within the hemoglobin molecule.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A reduction in the number of red blood cells, the amount of hemoglobin, and/or the volume of packed red blood cells. Clinically, anemia represents a reduction in the oxygen-transporting capacity of a designated volume of blood, resulting from an imbalance between blood loss (through hemorrhage or hemolysis) and blood production. Signs and symptoms of anemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability.
An inherited disorder characterized by structural alterations of a globin chain within the hemoglobin molecule.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
